awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Learning-based Navigation Technology-enabled Service Robots for the Retail Industry
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a retail service robot utilizing state-of-the-art, human-friendly navigation technology developed for densely crowded environments. As per the current industry estimates, retailers are losing $1 trillion worldwide due to inventory aberrations. Retail customers are frequently disappointed by out-of-stock items because of poor inventory management, leading to reduced customer loyalty. To survive current market trends in which most items may be purchased online, brick-and-mortar stores need to modernize, and use automated solutions wherever possible to free up associates’ time and focus more on the customer experience. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a robot enabled with state-of-the-art collision avoidance technology. It is capable of operating in crowds of a density greater than 1 person/square meter. The robot detects pedestrian movements using commodity visual sensors and smartly plans a path that is least obtrusive to humans. The collision avoidance technology also significantly reduces (by > 50%) the occurrence of the robot suddenly freezing or halting, which is a common phenomenon in dense scenarios. The I-Corps program will help better understand the applications of such a robot in the retail industry. The proposed robot will navigate in a densely crowded store and will perform volumetric scans to capture real-time data about the items on the shelves and customer buying patterns, leading to an increase in efficiency and accuracy in managing a store’s inventory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Key Outcomes: The main objective of participating in the I-Corps program was to find a commercialization pathway for our learning-based dense crowd navigation technology. We initiated the program with an aim of developing an inventory management robot for the retail stores. We believed an inventory management robot that can operate safely and reliably in densely populated retail stores can help the store owners to avoid inventory shortages. After conducting initial interviews in the retail industry we found that the margins in the retail industry were low and there was no pressing need for the proposed robot. We then started focusing on the warehouse industry. There as well, we found that our dense crowd navigation technology was not adding a significant value to the warehouse operators. During the exploratory interviews, we found a potential commercialization opportunity in the airport industry. The COVID-19 pandemic has reduced the confidence of people in using any services that involve human touch. This leads to a reduction in the non-aeronautical revenue through the sales of retail products. The airports are coming up with various innovative approaches to build the confidence of travelers. One such service is the food delivery service to the travelers at their gates. The airports are deploying various manual delivery services to address the need but these services are not economically viable and difficult to scale. Many airports are looking for delivery robots that can be deployed to serve travelers but the currently available robots are unable to work at the airport crowded places. We proposed to develop an autonomous delivery robot enabled by our dense crowd navigation technology.

During the I-Corps program, we conducted more than 60 interviews in the airport industry to understand the business model for the autonomous delivery robot enabled by our dense crowd navigation technology. Following are the key outcomes of the I-Corps program,

  1. Understood the customer discovery process by conducting more than 100 interviews with potential customers, partners, and vendors.
  2. Validated the value propositions and customer segment for the autonomous delivery robot through customer discovery,
  3. Received 3 letters of support from various decision makers acknowledging the need for such autonomous delivery robots that can work in airport like dense environments,

 

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, we did not get a chance to conduct in-person interviews during the I-Corps program. During the no-cost extension period, we continued our customer discovery in the airport industry and conducted additional in-person interviews. We attended AAAE/ACI-NA Airport Customer Experience Symposium in person from 7th to 9th March 2022. The in-person attendance helped us to connect with more decision-makers at the airport who are focused on improving the customer experience. We validated many of our hypotheses around the revenue model and the cost structure of the proposed product.

 

In addition to commercializing our technology through the development of delivery robots for the airport industry, we also explored the software licensing route to commercialize our technology. We attended the following conferences focused on the robotics industry.

  1. IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation (ICRA) 2022,
  2. Automate 2022,
  3. Autonomous Technologies Conference 2022.

The robotics industry-related conferences allowed us to understand the competitive landscape and explore the potential of the software licensing route. We connected with a few large robot manufacturers who showed interest in licensing our technology.

 


Last Modified: 08/18/2022
Modified by: Dinesh Manocha
